document_data.mainbody:
ile:Fey Crossroads.png|thumb|right|400px|A ''fey crossroad'' ''circa'' the late 14{{th}} century [[DR]].]]
'''Fey crossroads''' were [[magical]] portals, many of which led to the [[Feywild]]. They could be found all over [[Toril]], but most were hidden from casual view. They often required the use of a [[ritual]] to operate, and after the [[Spellplague]], many malfunctioned.
document_data.Description:
A fey crossroad, according to [[druid]]s, was where a fold in reality's ends touched each other, thus allowing instant travel by stepping in one end and coming out of the other. Each crossroad had a [[fey]] guardian, called a [[crossroad guardian]], who had to be convinced to allow usage of the crossroad. Fey received automatic permission. 

As a general rule, entrances were hidden from sight Most were large enough for a huge creature to fit through.

They were mapped by druids and known to some [[bard]]s; to other people, crossroads were more the stuff of legends than anything else.

Usage.Travel: The most notable use of a crossroad was to travel from one end of the crossroad to the other end in an instant. Interestingly, one could travel via crossroad without the traveler's intention, by accidentally stepping into a crossroad and coming out of the other end. Usually, this happened when the [[crossroad guardian]] gave unwanted permission to use a crossroad due to being impressed by the traveler's singing, which was mistaken for a plea to enter the crossroad.
Usage.Communication: Another use of a crossroad was to send acoustic messages through one end of a crossroad to another end. [[Druid]]s maintained schedules to send information to other druids.
Usage.Impossible Uses: Sound and people, if given permission, could travel through, but interestingly, one could not send an attack, in mundane or magical ways, through a crossroad to hit a far away place. It was also impossible to get visual information of the destination through a crossroad.

document_data.Guardian:
A [[crossroad guardian]] was an artificial [[fey]] with the duty to guard a crossroad. One guardian was stationed at each end of the crossroad. 

With increasing urbanity of the crossroad's area, a guardian grew increasingly hostile towards would-be users of its crossroad. They had a weakness for music, which was why bards had it easier to get permission then others.

People who wanted to use a crossroad couldn't just kill a guardian and get through, because a crossroad without a guardian ceased to function as an entry point, it could still be used but only one-way from the other side, given the guardian there wasn't killed beforehand.
document_data.Creation: Druids could cast the ''[[create crossroads and backroad]]'' spell to create a new crossroad with two ends and one crossroad guardian at each end.
